Teaser: QI Series M preview Excerpt from the upcoming season of QI, which will be Stephen Fry's last.
PT1M36S http://www.canberratimes.com.au/action/externalEmbeddedPlayer?id=d-44jo2 620 349 October 15, 2015 - 8:28AM Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Stephen Fry Marries Stephen Fry talks frankly about his cocaine habit After 13 seasons playing trivia master and asking thousands of inquisitorial questions of his hapless panellists on subjects as profound as pink polenta and hypochondria, Stephen Fry has announced he is quitting the comedy panel show QI . 
He will be replaced by sometime panellist, the Danish born comedian Sandi Toksvig, an appointment that will see her become the first female presenter of a mainstream TV comedy panellist show on the BBC. Toksvig was picked for her mixture of brains and naughtiness.
And that's it from Stephen Fry Photo: qi.com 
Via Twitter, Toksvig said she had massive shoes to fill.
Advertisement And today's quite interesting news is that I've been announced as the new presenter of Qi. My dream telly job and I have huge shoes to fill
— Sandi Toksvig (@sanditoksvig) October 14, 2015  
New host of QI: Sandi Toksvig Photo: Supplied 
Fry, the polymath, wasn't hired as host of  QI (or Quite Interesting) when the show was first broadcast in 2003. Fry was to be a team captain opposite Alan Davies but stood in for Michael Palin at the last minute, "just for the pilot [episode]".
When Palin dropped out altogether, Fry took over.
"For 13 years I had one of the best jobs on television," he said. "Behind the camera squadrons of quite extraordinarily brilliant researchers, programme makers and uniquely curious (in both senses of the word) people making that job so much easier.
"In front of the camera generations of lively minds and above all of course the wonder of nature that is Alan Davies."
The brainchild of former Blackadder and Not the Nine O'Clock News producer John Lloyd, QI took a letter of the alphabet to inspire each new series.
The next, "M", will go to air in Britain on Sunday.
"After passing the alphabetical halfway mark I thought it time to move on, but I will never cease to be grateful to John Lloyd for devising  QI  and for everyone else for making it such fun."
The announcement came as Fry is readying to tour Australia with his show  Telling Tales next month, and it's thought he will concentrate on his own productions.
Fry's career has taken him from the Cambridge Footlights where he met his long time collaborator Hugh Laurie to appearances on  Blackadder ,  Bones ,  V for Vendetta ,  Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows ,  Live Another Day and  The Hobbit  trilogy.
In addition to his work in television, radio and journalism, he has written four novels and three volumes of autobiography;  Moab is My Washpot ,  The Fry Chronicles  and  More Fool Me .
In 2013 a former senator and the president of Friends of the ABC in Tasmania, bemoaned the frequency with which the British comedian appeared on the ABC.
Panellist and Jonathan Creek star Alan Davies seems to be staying on despite changes at the top:
What's happening? A Dane you say?We'll all have pastries and jumpers and it'll be shot in black & white. Bye @stephenfry you did very well x
— Alan Davies (@alandavies1) October 14, 2015 A couple of weeks with a sobbing supply teacher would have been nice but no, a warm welcome to the brilliant @sanditoksvig 
— Alan Davies (@alandavies1) October 14, 2015  
Fry was touched.
Very touched by all your kind thoughts about QI. Leaving it in the best possible hands. Follow @qikipedia for eternal delight xx
— Stephen Fry (@stephenfry) October 14, 2015
